int create_nf ( const struct nfref *  ref,
int  flags 
) [inline]

Create a new notesfile.

Parameters:
ref A reference that will describe the new notesfile after it has been created.
flags A bitmap of flags to set in the newly-created notesfile; can include NF_ANONYMOUS, NF_LOCKED, and NF_MODERATED.
Returns:

struct nfref* nfref_alloc ( void   )  [read]

Create a new struct nfref.

Returns:
A newly allocated struct nfref. This should be freed with nfref_free when no longer needed.
See also:
nfref_free

int nfref_compare ( const struct nfref *  one,
const struct nfref *  two 
)

Compare two nfrefs, one and two, first alphabetically by owner then alphabetically by name. Both comparisons are case-sensitive, and NULL owner is considered "less-than" any non-NULL owner. Suitable as an argument to qsort(3) or other functions using the qsort interface.

Returns:
  • -1 if one is "less than" than two.
  • 0 if one and two are "equal".
  • 1 if one is "greater" than two.

void nfref_copy ( struct nfref *  dest,
const struct nfref *  source 
)

Duplicate an existing nfref. This is a deep copy; strings from source will be copied, and dest will point to those copied strings, not the originals from source. This function is safe to use if overwriting existing values in dest.

Parameters:
dest The nfref to copy values to.
source The nfref to copy values from.
Side effects:
The values stored in dest will be modified. Additionally, if dest was previously populated, its existing string elements will be freed before being overwritten.

void nfref_free ( struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Deallocate ref.

Side effects:
ref will be invalidated, and should no longer be used.
See also:
nfref_alloc

char* nfref_name ( const struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Return the name of the notesfile specified by ref.

See also:
nfref_set_name

char* nfref_owner ( const struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Return the owner of the notesfile specified by ref. NULL means that the notesfile is a global notesfile, not a private notesfile.

See also:
nfref_set_owner

unsigned short nfref_port ( const struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Return the port with which to access notesfile specified by ref.

See also:
nfref_set_port

char* nfref_pretty_name ( struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Return a user-readable pretty representation of the notesfile specified by ref. The output of this function should be able to be parsed with parse_single_nf or the other parsing functions to return an equivalent (although not necessarily identical) nfref.

enum notes_protocols nfref_protocol ( const struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Return the protocol to use to access the notesfile specified by ref.

See also:
nfref_set_protocol

int nfref_system_is_localhost ( const struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Return TRUE if the notesfile specified by ref refers to a notesfile on localhost, or FALSE otherwise.

This is defined to be true if nfref_system (ref) would return NULL, "", or "localhost".

FIXME: Obviously, this is a little braindead.

See also:
nfref_system

char* nfref_user ( const struct nfref *  ref  ) 

Return the user with which we're going to connect to the notesfile specified by ref.

FIXME: Is this really the right place for this? It's here because this is sort of a "how to get to this notesfile" spec, and if we're connecting to a foreign server the user we're connecting as is just as necessary a piece as the hostname, for example. But it still feels kludgy as heck.

See also:
nfref_set_user, nfref_system_is_localhost
